Ottawa February 22nd 1929.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, with which you submitted Voucher No 461 amounting to $124.40 in favour of the Skidegate Council, for repairs made to the house which was formerly rented for the teacher and nurse at Skidegate, and in reply I have to request that you will quote the authority for the Council having incurred the expense in question. The voucher (one copy) is returned herewith. It is not supported by receipts for expenditure incurred. Explanation and receipts are required before the Department will be prepared to give consideration to the question of payment.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith the Bills in connection with the repairs to the Nurse's and Teacher's residence at Skidegate. The amount is slightly over the estimate I gave, but I have had three bedrooms made on the second floor, so as to provide for the accommodation of a possible second teacher. On the ground floor there is a kitchen, pantry, dispensary, and dining and sitting room combined. I neglected to make any provision for the building of a chimney, so for the present stove pipe has been purchased and put in. I think, however, that a brick chimney would be better and safer, although very few houses in the village have them. I will find out the actual cost of one, and report on this later. The only outstanding bill in connection with this residence, is for the moving of the furniture and drugs etc., from the old place. This has not yet come to hand.

Your obedient servant,

Form No. 11
Ottawa, 6th April, 1929.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 23rd ultimo, and previous correspondence regarding the building at Skidegate which was occupied by the teacher and nurse, I have to inform you that receipts covering the expenditure incurred for repairs are required before the Department will give consideration to the question of paying the accounts which you submitted.

I have to point out also that you have not answered the enquiry in official letter of the 22nd February as to "whether the house has been rented, and if so by whom it will be occupied?" Information on this point should be supplied.

The Voucher submitted requests payment in favour of the Skidegate Council. In the event of the issue of a cheque the Department wishes to be informed what the Council would do with the money if paid to them. If it is the Council's desire that the money be used for the benefit of the band in general it seems advisable to leave it for the present to credit of the band account, and later an application can be made for expenditure in a judicious manner, so that the Indians in general may benefit from the use of the money.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Revd J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Massett, B.C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6413, file 843-8, part 1)
Dear Sir,

Replying to the Departmental letter No.157-11-S, of Feb. 22nd, 1929, I beg to say that the material mentioned in voucher No. 401 was purchased in January 1928. The Skidegate Council at that time fixed up the building so that the teacher and nurse could occupy it. Up until that time they had been boarding at the Mission House, but this arrangement was found unsatisfactory. As no other house was available at that time, the Council repaired the place with the understanding that the Department would rent it for the teacher and nurse, and the rent paid directly to the Council, which would compensate for the material and labour on the repairs. The rent however, has been paid into their Trust Fund.

Departmental letter No. 157-11-S of Dec. 29th, 1927, which confirmed a telegram contained the following, "... You may prepare house for teacher and nurse at Skidegate..........." The Council offered to put the house in good shape and rent it. This I thought a better plan than having it done at the Department's expense, as the idea was that it would only be a temporary residence for the teacher and nurse. There were no bills, therefore, submitted to the Department for repairs to the building, but vouchers were sent for rental, and these were paid to the Trust Fund of the Band.

There were no receipts sent in with Voucher 401 as the Council had purchased the material, and the receipts were not kept. The items in Voucher 401 were copied from the Council's books at Skidegate. Matthew Williams, the Hardware merchant, has since given me a receipt for the material which was purchased at his store. According to the Council's books the shingles and lumber was purchased from various individuals in the village and at Queen Charlotte City. No bills were secured from the different parties. The material was used in repairing the building, woodshed and toilet, and I certify to the correctness of this statement.

March 23rd, 1929

Ottawa, September 6, 1929.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 14th ultimo, in which you state that Mr. James Martin claims that cheque No. 7357 issued to him last March, payment for pipes and fittings for Skidegate teacher's residence, was for only $10.05, I would say that the cheque which is at headquarters shows that it was drawn for $14.05 and was cashed on the 22nd March, in the Bank of Commerce, at Prince Rupert. Ottawa, August 3, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th ultimo, relative to the renovating of the house used as a residence for the teacher and nurse at Skidegate, also to the erection of a new chimney and the supplying of a quantity of furnishings.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have a brick chimney erected. We note that you estimate the cost of material and labour in the building of this chimney to be approximately $60.

You may also arrange to have the whole house given a fresh coat of kalsomine and the floors painted. It is noted that the approximate cost of the labour and material in carrying out this work will amount to $60.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery, for the residence, of the following furniture:

- Small dining set, table and four chairs,
- Two dressers for bedrooms,
- Living room suite (7 piece),
- 2 Congoleum rugs,
- 1 Bed, spring and mattress,

also for the freight, cartage, setting up, etc., of same. We note that you estimate the cost, including freight, etc., to be $130.70.

After all the above work has been carried out to your satisfaction and the furniture supplied, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Massett, B.C.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Dear Sir,

In the allowance made for the renovating of the house for the use of the teacher and nurse at Skidegate, no provision was made for a brick chimney. I think it would be advisable to have one erected. Five hundred brick will be necessary. The approximate cost would be,

Brick, delivered at Skidegate... $20.00
Hauling to residence............. 5.00
Lime and sand delivered......... 3.00
Labour bricklaying............... 25.00
Lumber for foundation............ 2.00

$60.00

I would like to recommend also that the whole house be given a fresh coat of kalsomine, and the floors painted. The new work done last year was not kalsomined, and all the old walls needs a fresh coat. The approximate cost for labour and material for this would be $60.00.

I would also recommend that the following furniture be purchased for the residence, counting on a second teacher, and also the nurse. One bureau, 2 beds etc., are already in the house.

Small dining set, table, four chairs.... $21.50
Two dressers for bedrooms.......... $12.00 ea. $24.00
Living room suite (7-piece)........... $37.50

Ottawa, May 6, 1932.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your letter of the 25th ultimo, informing the Department of the repairs and painting required to the roof of the teacher's residence at the Skidegate Indian Day School, I have to say that we will have no funds this year to carry out any extensive work at this school.

I have to request that you will state whether any reshingling is urgent or if this work could not stand over for another year. If, however, you consider that certain work should be carried out, I would request that you state, in detail, the amount of shingling you would recommend be done and the approximate cost of same, including material and labour. We would not be prepared to authorize any expenditure this year in staining the roof. When we have information as to the cost of the shingling necessary, consideration will then be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided or not.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 13, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, giving an estimate of the material and cost of the labour in carrying out the shingling and repairs required to the teachers' residence at the Skidegate Indian Day School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated Oct 9th, 1945, in respect to the proposed improvements at the Teachers Residence at Skidegate Mission, B.C. and have attached herewith an estimate of the cost of materials and labour.

It is proposed to install a new 30 Gal hot water tank connected from stove, and to supply hot water on the sink in the kitchen, also to connect the bath for hot water also, (the present bath is not connected for hot or cold water) also the waste from the bath was a rubber hose hanging through the floor into a wooden trough under the house this was not boxed in, and was exposed, which was unsanitary, the labour for this particular work is very reasonable as the pipes will leading from the bath will be covered and run out into a rock pit. This will also take the waste water from the kitchen sink.

The Materials can be supplied by W.J. Davies at Queen Charlotte City, who has all the fittings etc. on hand and is expecting water tanks in the near future.

I would appreciate an early reply,

Mr. Indian Agent Phillips has recommended the supply of various furnishings and kitchen utensils for the teachers' residence at the Skidegate Indian Day School. These are obtainable in Vancouver at a cost of $140.00 for furniture and $40.00 for kitchen utensils.

I may say that the kitchen utensils consist of dishes, the usual cooking equipment, washtub, broom, etc., and the furnishings, two chairs, one drop leaf table, one studio lounge, two easy chairs and one dinette suite.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Referring to my letter dated February 23rd, 1945, file 11-76 in which I advised that the roof of the teachers' residence at Skidegate Mission only leaked during westerly gales, however this has got gradually worse, so I took it upon myself to have a new valley put in and the shingling made good; this was done in view of the very dry weather we have had, and the teachers report that the roof is now alright, and does not leak in the part repaired or any other part as far as is known, as we are having a very long dry spell, and will have to wait for a good wet storm to test the work now completed.

I hope you will approve of my action in this matter, as it is hard to get any help on the reserve, as they like to repair boats etc. in the good weather.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Prefabricated Schools and Teacherages.

As you are aware, the Department is seriously considering the use of prefabrication as a means of constructing needed schools and teacherages.

Our Lands and Development Services branch have recently made a careful study of plans submitted by North American Builders, Limited, of Winnipeg, and Prefabricated Builders Limited, Vancouver. You will be particularly interested in their comments regarding "Prefabricated Buildings Limited":

"This company supplied blueprints of three cottages, their "Dogwood," "Laurel," and "Redwood" designs. The same general comments apply. Roof slopes, except the "Redwood" are dangerously flat for shingle covering. Chimney designs are better, but exterior elevations generally leave something to be desired. Also, vestibule entrances are not provided, and these are essential in most parts of Canada, except perhaps southwest British Columbia.

"This Company, however, provides construction details, including foundations. These are based on structural unit prefabrication, a system successfully used by Peerless Housing, Limited, and one which permits greater flexibility in design. This system is adaptable to custom design.

"To use the products of these firms, it would evidently be most expedient to select one of their stock designs, and then to have made the minimum alterations required for efficient and safe construction. Cost and the amount of time involved would have to be the subject of further enquiry.

"It should be noted that these firms provide only the..."
frame and exterior covering for a building. Plumbing, heating, electrical services, insulation, some interior finish and the foundations would have to be supplied by this Department in the usual way."

(a) Prefabricated Schools

Please find attached the letter from this Company. It is suggested that Inspector Davy contact this company with a view to ascertaining their interest in prefabricating our standard one-room school and attached teacher's residence. Additional sets of these blueprints are available here.

(b) Prefabricated Teacherages

It is recommended also that he investigate the possibility of having the teacher's residence for Skidegate built by this company. We have included the sum of $5,000.00 in our Estimates for this construction. It is presumed that the residence required will be for two teachers. Therefore, under separate cover, I am forwarding a set of the drawings for a caretaker's residence which might prove satisfactory.

You will note that Prefabricated Buildings Limited have already seen this plan (29) and have a standard house which is somewhat similar.

In addition to the above, there is the possibility that a foreman-carpenter, who could supervise the construction of this building, might be available at Skidegate.

Any information which you might obtain from this company will be also referred to Miss Walton here, as she is interested from the point of view of constructing new agencies' residences.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Skidegate Teacherage.

I have your letter of May 27th advising of the proposed erection of a Model "F" Multi-Flex building for use as a teacherage at Skidegate. I shall be at Skidegate later in the week and shall report in detail upon my return. However, the following pertinent facts are presented for your consideration.

1. Site: The ideal site for the teacherage is the one upon which the present residence stands. This is land released by the Band for school purposes and being adjacent to the school building allows for close supervision of school and property at all times. I would strongly urge that the present residence be dismantled and the new building erected on the same site.

2. Salvage: Material salvaged from present residence can be used to erect a utility room at rear of new house. Some storage space for trunks, etc. is imperative and the necessary space can be provided by such construction. New woodsheds for school fuel are needed and these can be erected from salvaged material.

3. Basement: A basement is not essential. The excavation for such would perhaps be rather costly since I know that shale and rocks are to be found at the depth of ground to be excavated for a basement.

4. Foundation: Either of the following should be provided.
   (a) Concrete posts sunk to hardpan.
   (b) Concrete curb to hardpan.

5. Heating: We do not suffer from extreme weather on the Islands and the excavation of a basement to install a furnace is not necessary. It would, in any event, be an added hardship to the teachers if they
had to tend a furnace. I strongly urge that a circulating heater (oil) be purchased for this purpose. Such can be allowed to burn at low fire during the winter months thus keeping the house comfortable at all times. I would also advise a new oil burning kitchen range. (Queen)

I shall advise you upon my return concerning cost of labour of

1. Dismantling old residence.
2. Available labour for foundation work.
3. Cost of labour in preparing foundation.

J.A. Findley,
Superintendent,
Queen Charlotte Agency.

Re: Teacherage - Skidegate

Before leaving Skidegate I had another interview with Peter Martin regarding the dismantling of the present teachers' residence. Together we went over the house and surveyed the entire situation.

Peter came to see me later and stated that he would accept the contract for $250.00. He based his estimate on the following:

1. It would take at least two men (to be paid out of the contract price)
   a. House to be completely dismantled.
   b. Wood sheds to be removed.
   c. As much material salvaged as possible.
   d. Salvaged material piled at rear of lot.
   e. Site entirely cleared in readiness for new foundation.
2. Approximately two weeks needed to complete the contract.

In my estimation this would appear to be fair and I pointed out to him that if he was awarded the contract the work was to be done exactly as detailed above.

He is actually the only man available and I recommend that approval be given as soon as possible to this arrangement. I would also urge that the sum of $250.00 be forwarded as an accountable advance. Upon completion of the work this amount will be paid and the necessary receipt taken. I request this for two reasons:
1. Our infrequent mail services.
2. The delay in payment being made in submitting vouchers after such work is completed is always a reason for impatience on the part of the worker. They like to be paid as their work is finished.

I would appreciate your advice in the matter as soon as possible.

Re: Teacherage - Skidegate.

I wish to acknowledge your letters of June 23rd and 25th enclosing plans and blue prints for the proposed teachers residence at Skidegate. At this date I am waiting a reply to my wire to your office regarding dismantling of the old residence in order that concrete foundation may be completed as soon as possible.

Following are arrangements made and which I hope will be approved.

1. There is no experienced man available at Skidegate or Queen Charlotte City who can supervise mixing and pouring of concrete.

2. There is no mixer available at the south end.

3. Should all cement have to be mixed by hand, the cost would be considerable.

4. A building contractor in Masset, experienced in such work has signified his willingness to do the job.

5. A small portable mixer is available here.

6. Details of amount of concrete:
   Depth of excavation - 33 - 36 inches.
   Height of concrete above ground - 2ft. 8 inches.
   Thickness of wall - 8 inches.
   Total height of concrete - 5ft. 8 inches.
   Volume of concrete - 465 cu. ft.
   Mixture - 1 to 5 (sand and gravel mixed)
   Cement needed - 100 sacks.
   Gravel - local.

Mr. Howard Phillips, the contractor mentioned, has offered to take the work on a contract basis and his price makes allowances for:

1. Wages for himself and Skidegate Indian.
2. Hire of mixer and owner who runs it.
3. Return transportation for himself and Mr. Lindsay, owner of mixer (asset to Skidegate)
4. Return freight on mixer.
5. Maintenance at Skidegate.

The work involves excavation, planning, frame work, mixing and pouring of concrete, leveling etc. Mr. Phillips contracts for the above at $350.00.

Considering that there is excavation to a depth of 3 ft., all frame work to be done, and 465 cu. ft. of concrete to be poured, I consider his price a fair one. I strongly urge that this amount of $350.00 be forwarded here in order that the contractor be paid without delay at the completion of the work. I do not consider it necessary to enter into a formal written contract with him, since he has done considerable work for me on other occasions and has always been satisfactory.

It is to be noted that if this work was to be done by an inexperienced man - on day labor basis - and the concrete mixed by hand, the costs involved would be considerable. I feel that having made the above arrangements, the work is being done at minimum cost and a great deal of anxiety will be avoided by having an experienced man on the job.

I may say that it was through personal friendship that I persuaded Mr. Phillips to undertake the work, since he has other contracts to fill this summer.

The plans for the house have been studied very carefully and would appear to indicate that a quite satisfactory building is being provided as a residence.

However, the plans indicate a fireplace but no details are listed anywhere in the list of instructions or checking sheet. Thus, I presume that the supplying company does not include such in their contract. If this is the case, I would appreciate having information concerning this item. The fact that a fireplace may be installed, and provision has been made in partitioning, etc., for one, will not eliminate the need for an oil heater. Can a heatlaster be acquired for installation in the fireplace? In any event a chimney must be built and materials for this will have to be shipped in from Vancouver. This work, I believe can also be undertaken by Mr. Phillips.

Materials to be shipped from Vancouver to Skidegate:

100 sacks cement. (for foundation)
1000 bricks for chimney (double flue) and fireplace.
30 flue linings 8" x 6"
4 sacks cement.
5 sacks lime.
Contract prices.

Total expense (less materials) involved in foundation work - $350.00

Building chimney and fire place - $125.00

These amounts to be forwarded as accountable advance to be supported by necessary receipts.

Gravel for all concrete work can be obtained in the vicinity of Skidegate and since other items such as wire, bolts, nails, lumber (over material which can be salvaged from old house) will have to be purchased, plus cartage of gravel, I would request that a further sum of $200.00 be forwarded to meet any such expenses.

It is my belief that the total cost of the house should not exceed $5000.00 and I would appreciate having the necessary funds advanced for the work as requested.

J. A. Findlay,
Superintendent,
Queen Charlotte Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa

I have to report that all concrete work has been completed in preparation for the erection of the new residence at Skidegate. The workers were extremely fortunate in having perfect weather and should it continue the actual erection of the building should progress rapidly.

I would request authority to dispose of several items from the old building for sale. There are a number of doors, windows, and a quantity of wall board which when trimmed could be put to good use. Several people have applied to purchase this and money realized would assist in paying for items needed to complete the new building.

Freight charges have been enormous and although I believe the total costs involved in the actual erection of the building will not exceed $5000.00 we shall have to use every dollar to best advantage. The sale of the above articles would cover costs of necessary paint, for example, and perhaps pay for some of the labor involved.

Since Skidegate Village has the only real water system on the Islands, and several of the Indians have up to date plumbing installed in their homes, I would most certainly regret it if we were unable to install proper plumbing in the teachers residence. There is plenty of pipe on hand and the following are needed:

1 toilet (complete - white)
1 wash basin (wall type)
1 wood septic tank. (Valley lumber Yard)

The bath, which is the only item of plumbing which was in the previous house, can be used for a year and replaced at a later date.

I recommend that you order the above items with fittings to be shipped to Skidegate as soon as possible.
The problem of new stoves should be considered now. As in previous correspondence, I strongly recommend that the present kitchen range and heater be replaced with oil burning stoves. Teachers who are in school all day are greatly inconvenienced when having to return to the house to light new fires each time. I hope the cost of these will not be a charge against the $500.00 which sum is for actual construction. If so, it will be impossible to take any action in purchasing such stoves at this time.

If it is at all possible I would urge that these be purchased and shipped as soon as possible.

Kitchen Range - medium sized, with Queen Oil Burner installed.

Heater - quaker - medium sized.

With reference to the sum of $463.25 for unpaid labor, this is made up of $119.00 owing to Peter Martin and $344.25 owing to H. Phillips. Mr. Phillips' account for day labor exceeded this amount but he spent a considerable number of extra hours on the job and only rendered the above amount for his labor. He considered the work of erecting the pre-fab house as a type of experiment for himself since it was the first he had handled in that way. He also asked that money already advanced be paid to the other workers and that he would wait until a further advance was received after a review of costs was made.
Figures as shown above indicate total cost and although in excess of the $5000.00 I do not see how it could have been done for less. A six room house built for approximately $6000.00 averages $1000.00 per room which is much less than the per room cost estimated by Vancouver contractors in house construction.

I would appreciate receiving the following:

1. Purchase Orders as requested.
2. Accountable advance for $565.00 to pay labor owing and to allow for completion of plumbing work.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Federal Bldg., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Teacherage, Skidegate.

I have just returned from Skidegate and report as follows on the construction of the new teachers residence there.

1. Exterior of house completed (except small portion of siding). In this respect I may say that the exact amount as listed (8 bundles, $90) was received, but an error must have been made by the supplying company in computing the amount necessary. There was no wastage and $50 are needed to complete the exterior of the building. Siding has been given one prime coat of white paint.

2. Interior completed as follows:

(a) All walls lined.
(b) Doors hung.
(c) Window & door frames completed.
(d) Gyproc on walls.
(e) Cracks filled & sanded.
(f) Flooring laid.
(g) Cupboards completed.
(h) Walls sized.

When I left Skidegate, interior decorating in some of the rooms was about to be started.

3. Since delay was caused by non-arrival of the heatillator, I was forced to cancel same, as it was necessary to proceed with erection of the chimney. Mr. Phillips, who has shown great interest in the work was considering construction of an ordinary brick fireplace. I did not insist on it but I shall be phoning him today and will learn what action he has taken in the matter.
4. Review of costs.

Dismantling $250.00
Cost of house 2712.00
Freight on house 352.25
Cement, bricks, etc. 153.70
Freight (approx.) 80.00
Concrete (labor) 350.00
Brickwork (labor) 125.00
Cartage of materials 80.00
Sand, gravel, etc. 63.00
Labor adv. (to be rec'd) 500.00

4665.95

Freight charges and unforeseen increased cost of materials may cause the total costs to slightly exceed the $5000.00. If plumbing supplies are to be purchased from this amount. To date the plumbing material ordered, including septic tank have not been received and completion of the work will be held up until it reaches Skidegate.

I may say that Mr. Phillips has rushed the job and the men have voluntarily spent a number of extra hours on the work.

I have not yet received the $500.00 referred to in your letter of August 18th, but expect it may arrive by next mail. I would request that an additional $300.00 be forwarded to meet labour costs.

J.A. Findlay,
Superintendent,
Queen Charlotte Agency.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SKIDEGATE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL - (Date of Inspection May 29/36).

Original on File 157-11-6.

I would recommend that more attention be given to handicrafts. Some of the older boys might well be taught to carve the black slate totem poles for which the Queen Charlotte Islands are famous and for which there is always a ready sale. There is plenty of space in the large hall of this school to fix up the necessary tables at which to work. Either James McKay, Edward Collinson, or John Cross, Indians, who are good carvers of these slate totem poles, might be willing to give instruction for a small sum. The slate would have to be purchased. The whole of the work should be under the direct supervision of the Senior Teacher and should take place in the afternoon school time on say one afternoon per week from perhaps November to March, inclusive.

I also would recommend that the older girls be taught fine basket work. It is a pity to see this die out in the village. Mrs. Tulip speaks English and makes good baskets. She might possibly be given an opportunity to teach this native work on another afternoon during school hours. Space could be found for this in the school hall. Certain materials would of course be wanted.

A total of perhaps $100 might well be set aside from the B.C. Special Vote for this Vocational Work which I believe would prove of the greatest possible value to the children here. I should certainly like to see Vocational Work encouraged in the Indian Day Schools, as it will be of much greater importance to the Indians than much which is taught in the Senior Grades.

I have given the teacher, Miss Phillips, as much help as possible, spending the morning and afternoon sessions in her room. She will I am certain respond well to the suggestions made. The schoolroom is bright and clean. There were flowers in the windows. A small children's library has been established. There were a number of well made Reading and Number Charts. With the exception of the discipline, which I consider a little weak, I was very well pleased with all I saw. The general standing of the school may be classed as "Good".
Sir:

Masset, B.C.

I have to report as follows for the Queen Charlotte Agency for the month of November 1938.

The average attendance for the Massett Indian day school was senior class 38.00 and the Junior class 38.43 at the Skidegate School the averages were Senior Class 19.52 the Junior Class 27.32. I was successful in securing Black Slate for use in the Vocational class for the making of Totem Poles etc. I have not yet secured the services of an Instructor to teach same, but hope to get this going in the near future. Dyes were given to both schools for use in basket making, these classes are proving to be very interesting to the pupils who look forward to the above work.

B.T. Phillips,
Acting Indian Agent.
I made my usual visit to the Skidegate reserve, held Council meeting visited and inspected Day school, dispensary, interviewed Fild matron, also teacher of basketry. Basketry at this school is doing very well indeed, but at the time of my visit, the Slate Totem Carving had not started, this was taken up at the Council meeting, and was assured that they would do their best to get someone to teach the pupils, other matters were taken up beneficial to the reserve, Numerous requests for relief asked for were attended to.

B. T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
Queen Charlotte Agency, B.C.
April 5th, 1946.

REPORT FOR MARCH QUARTER

EDUCATIONAL:

The schools of both the Massett and Skidegate Reserves were visited several times each month. At the Skidegate school the teacher of the senior room has her class well disciplined, also in this class manual training has been introduced, and the boys have made a bookcase with doors, and shelves for their room. I have recommended that tools be purchased for their use, to encourage them in this work. At the Massett school both the teachers commenced their duties in February, and are doing very well with their classes. They are very active in social work on the Reserve, have a teenage canteen and a kindergarten for those under school age under their supervision. The junior teacher (Mrs Conroy) was taken out by plane March 17th with a throat affection to Prince Rupert, but returned to her duties March 25th. Both teachers are very well liked by the Indians of the Reserve.

B. T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.

Sir:-

In reply to your letter of July 2nd, last, File No. 411846/1, dealing with a recommendation of His Grace Archbishop McNeill of Vancouver with respect to the establishment of a day school at Chilliwack, I beg to report as follows:-

In my opinion there are sufficient children of school age on the Reserve of the Catholic Faith to warrant the establishment of a day school, and a good average attendance at the same. This matter I discussed with Chief Harry Stewart of the Squah Reserve in April last, and again on my recent visit to Chilliwack. I read to him the contents of the Department's letter, and he has promised to lay the matter before the Indians to see how far they would assist in the building of the School, and how many children they will guarantee being regular attendants, and to write to me as to what conclusions they have come to. This information I will forward to the Department as soon as it is received.

As to the suggestion of His Grace the Archbishop that the teacher should have a practical knowledge of Agriculture, I do not think that it would be necessary, for he would have very little time at his disposal to

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
to devote to giving instruction in farming. I think, however, that in the event of a school being established the Department should be prepared to pay the teacher a salary equivalent to that paid by the Provincial Government to its teachers in rural schools of the same grade, which I find upon perusal of the Reports are not less than $50.00 per month.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Pedley,

In April 1912, His Grace Archbishop McNeill, then Archbishop of Vancouver, brought to the attention of the Department the necessity of a school at the Chilliwack district. The suggestion was that the Indians would build a school if the Department would provide the salary of the teacher. The matter has been gone into by Mr. Inspector Ditchburn, who under date of last instant reports that these Indians while expressing their desire for a school have not funds to put up a building.

A school could be centrally located to serve five reserves and also two others about two miles distant. The Chief states that an average attendance of 35 children would be assured.

It would appear advisable to provide educational facilities for these reserves. The Department has a plan for a modest building to accommodate 40 pupils which might be used. And I would recommend that the work be taken as soon as possible. Funds will be available from the school vote of the current year. If you approve kindly indicate the papers in which the advertisement for tenders should appear.

Sir,

With further reference to the subject of the establishment of an Indian Day School at Chilliwack, B.C., as contained in your letter of 2nd July last (file 411846/1), an interim report on which I forwarded on the 11th September, 1912 (521/B), I beg to state that I received a letter from Chief Harry Stewart of the Skwah reserve (the most populous Indian settlement at Chilliwack) during the month of March, in which he informed me that the Indians had held a meeting at which all the Indians expressed their desire that a Day School should be established there, but that they were not able to raise enough money to pay for the building.

On the 24th of April I was at Chilliwack and went to see Chief Stewart, and he corroborated the statements made in his letter, that the Indians were not able to pay for the building of a school, but that they would give a piece of land upon which the school might be erected and sufficiently large enough for a playground, centrally located and in close proximity to the surrounding reserves.

The reserves in this section of the Chilliwack Municipality are the Skwah (Soowali) No. 6, Skwah No. 4, Skway No. 5, Klaw-kwaw-ah-pilt No. 6, and Squia-ala No. 7, and have a total population of 215 Indians, with 42 children between 6 and 15 years of age. There are also some children on the Tzeachteen and the Yuk-kwe-kwi-oose reserve who might be able to attend the

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
the school, though these two reserves are about two miles distant.

Chief Harry Stewart states that they could be sure of an average attendance of 35 children at least. The Chilliwack Indians as a rule do not leave their reserves to go to the canneries during the fishing season, but all take part in the hop-picking at Chilliwack in September and the children also go to the hop fields. The Chief is of the opinion that if a school is to be built that arrangements should be made that the holidays should be given in the month of September instead of July so that there would not be too many breaks in the school terms.

I have no hesitation in saying that a day school, conducted by a competent teacher, would prove of much benefit to the Indians of Chilliwack, and that one should be established there, large enough to accommodate at least forty pupils.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Ritter

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Visits have been paid from time to time to the different industrial and Boarding schools and instruction in horticultural matters given wherever possible. Sir:-

Owing to the comparatively small salary paid to the teachers of Indian Schools in this Province, it is very difficult at times to get a competent person to take on the work. When the new school on the Skwah Indian Reserve is open we expect an attendance of from thirty-five to forty pupils and it is the intention to cultivate a field of some five or six acres in the vicinity of the building, and to instruct the boys in the growing of grain, vegetables and all kinds of small fruits.

Mr. T. Wilson, Inspector of Indian Orchards, has taken a great interest in this work of encouraging the Indians to cultivate the soil and grow crops to the best advantage, and I can assure the Department that the education of the Indian children along these lines will be very beneficial to them. In order to carry out the work as outlined, it would be advisable to have a man and his wife in charge of this school, and as Mr. Grimshaw states in his application, it would be desirable if the Department favourably consider the erection of a small cottage, about four rooms, where the teacher and his family could reside. I believe that the cost of such a cottage would not exceed $1,000.00, and the advantages to the Department and the Indians, in having a permanent and satisfactory teacher would be great, as the Indians study very much better under the directions of a teacher with whom they are well acquainted than they would with a stranger.
I may add that at most of the other Indian schools, accommodation is provided for the teacher in the same building in which the classes are held, but the building at Skwah being only one story does not allow for this. I would therefore respectfully recommend that the Department favourably consider the erection of a cottage.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

For the information of the Department I beg to report that I visited the Skwah Indian Day School on the 7th ultimo, there were 10 children present, 6 in the first standard and 4 in the second. I regret to state that the attendance continues small, although I have spoken to the Chief and members of the Band, and urged upon them the necessity of giving their children an education, particularly when such a good opportunity is afforded them to do so. I believe it is impossible to force the parents to send their children to school, the only satisfactory method being persuasion and encouragement, in fact they need coaxing, as it is difficult to drive Indians. We hope, however, to have a better attendance as soon as the Indians have finished their spring planting and return to their village. Generally speaking, the health of the children is good and they are making rapid progress.

Mr. MacKenzie,

Mr. Walter H. Grimshaw, who claims the full bonus of $420.00, first entered the service of the Department on March 5, 1914, at the time the Skwah Day School was first started. His salary was at the rate of $600.00 per annum, which was increased on April 1st, 1918, to $750.00, and further increased to $900.00 per annum from January 1st, 1919.

There is an enrolment of 24 pupils and an average attendance of 12.

He has no teacher's certificate and, except for the five years he has been in this school, has had no experience. Mr. Inspector Cairns states that the teacher's methods and his manner do not tend to bring out the best from the pupils. The senior pupils read and spell fairly well, but they cannot do much in Arithmetic. They can do the simple rules, but fail in the application of them and it is difficult to get them to answer questions. He says the teacher seems to take particular pride in the junior pupils and wanted him to note how well they did, but he failed to see anything remarkable in their work. He further states that he is convinced that the school will not reach a high standard under Mr. Grimshaw. He states that the teacher is neat and orderly and keeps everything tidy and has many admirable characteristics.

Mr. Grimshaw received a bonus for the fiscal year 1918-19 of $150.00 and is being paid at the same rate for the present fiscal year.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am informed that Mr. Grimshaw, principal of the Chilliwack Indian Day School, has been granted leave of absence on account of ill health, till the end of July, but with half pay only until the end of March 1925.

Most probably nothing has been said to you of the nature of Mr. Grimshaw's sickness, but it is general belief here that the poor man is suffering from cancer in the throat, or some other fatal disease which he may have contracted in the discharge of his many years of service among the Indians.

We consider his case to be quite hopeless and are advising him to return with his wife to England. Unfortunately his funds are very low and for this reason I now appeal to the Department to grant him his regular salary up to the end of the scholastic year. This I judge could easily be allowed as you already have the appropriation for that period, one quarter's salary is not a big amount but under the circumstances would benefit him immensely.

May I be permitted to add that the school attendance in Chilliwack is invariably small after Easter, and as Mr. Grimshaw will continue to occupy the teacher's cottage for a couple of months or more, he may reasonably be considered to be at his post until the end of the present term.

In making my urgent request I can assure you that I am not alone, in fact I feel safe in saying that every person in this Agency, who is in anyway connected with the Indian Department, will support me.

Looking forward to a favorable reply,

I have the honour to be,

Yours respectfully,

I have made a study of payments that have been made to teachers of Indian day schools upon retirement. The Department has decided that, whereas they appear to be in the class known as 'temporary Civil Servants', they are not eligible for superannuation under the 1924 Act. (See file #129-18).

I have learned that in the past there have been payments of a gratuity or retiring allowance in the case of 9 teachers. (See list attached). The amounts of the payments varied from 2 to 6 months' salary. Vouchers were prepared showing that the payments were retiring allowances or gratuities. No authority was secured other than that of the Deputy Superintendent General, and on one or two occasions that of the Hon. the Minister. The Auditor General to my knowledge - and I have carefully examined the files - has never questioned these payments.

It was the Department's wish to give a gratuity in the case of the teacher of the Skawah Indian School, who suffered from ill-health during the last few months of his incumbency, and died during the summer months. Mr. Paget and Mr. MacKenzie are of the opinion that authority is necessary before any payment of more than 2 months' salary can be given. I phoned Mr. Douglas, of the Auditor General's Department, and he concurs in this opinion.

On at least three occasions (see list attached), teachers of Indian day schools, who have given long service, have been granted not only two months' gratuity but an annuity. Authority of His Excellency in Council was secured for each of these actions.

Dear Captain Barry:

I feel impelled to apologize for the grave inconvenience and discourtesy of my conduct on last Monday. Such an attitude is altogether contrary to my nature, and was altogether unworthy of me.

The only explanation, (and that a poor one) is that Mrs. Moroney and I had spent two miserable days trying to keep the house warm. In spite of two big fires, every pipe in the house froze, including the sink and the toilet, and to add to our misfortunes, the pipe burst and flooded the house. But these trials were no excuse for my not being prepared for you.

Mrs. Moroney joins me in this apology, and trusts that you will pardon her too. We now realize the grave inconvenience you were put to, and we regret sincerely any disrespect which we may have been guilty of.

Trusting that you will accept this sincere apology from us both

I am, dear Captain,

Very sincerely yours,

"J.J. Moroney"

Captain G.H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools,
Victoria, B.C.

March 8, 1932

Dear Sir:

Our agent Mr. Smith, informed us today that owing to the report of Inspector Barry, the District Head had decided to transfer Mrs. Murray and myself to Fort Barrie. This information was astounding and distressing to us both. We regard it as unfortunate and disturbing to us both. We regard it as unfortunate and disturbing to us both. We regard it as unfortunate and disturbing to us both. We regard it as unfortunate and disturbing to us both.

In justice to Mrs. Murray and myself, I feel what should write to you to inquire why we should be so treated in such a manner. We charge that we have been treated unfairly and unjustly. We believe that our complaints will have always been heard, and I think they have stood well in the estimation of the officials of the Department, at least those who knew us well, seem to be a difficult question to solve.

It seems to me that we are accused of dishonesty. I feel there is one thing that we should faithfully do. The following are the facts as I know them.

I met Inspector Barry on the streets of Chilliwack on Wednesday Jan. 27. After a few minutes, I asked him when we might expect him. He told me he did not know what he might be recalled to Ottawa, as the Commissioner was in the hospital dangerously ill. Later he said that it would probably only be next week. His last words were, "Now, mind I promise nothing."

On Friday night a fierce north-east wind set in. The wind is the terror of the people here. It usually blows for three or four days, and, like all blizzards it's dangerous to be out in it. Our cottage, a frame building could not be got out in it. Our cottage, a frame building could not be got out in it. Our cottage, a frame building could not be got out in it. Our cottage, a frame building could not be got out in it. Our cottage, a frame building could not be got out in it. Our cottage, a frame building could not be got out in it.

The wind died down somewhat.
During Sunday night but was still blowing on Monday morning. We have been three hundred cases of measles in the town and vicinity, our doctor has warned Mrs. Johnson to be extremely careful, so in addition to measles the town was threatened with smallpox which had to be put out in December and while everybody knew this disease that it would be dangerous to have the children out. Our school at Edward is probably one of the best we have. It has, however, a metal ceiling with two large ventilators in it, and a single ventilator on the roof; as a consequence, it is almost impossible to get the temperature above 35° when the North east wind blows.

When the Inspector came, however, he would listen to no explanation. He ordered me respectfully to go to the school, and spoke in such a harsh manner that I was astounded. We went into the school. The thermometer was 18° - a temperature that he insisted was high enough to open school with. He spoke so angrily that I remember that I did not make any of my excuses but let him state it in such harsh terms that I thought that we were allowed to exercise some judgment in such a state of affairs. This only angered him. He then told me that I had treated him with discourtesy; that I had let him come down to the school after he had told me he was coming; that he had heard discourse, and did not expect to lie long, etc., etc. He was so much agitated that I did not say a single word, except to give him whatever satisfaction he asked for. He then left quite coolly, leaving some of his belongings which I had to mail after him. Among the contents, however, what pains me most was the following note: "I told you last year that I was dissatisfied with the way you conducted this school, and that I would give you one more chance." Now the fact was, we had only a few weeks together after this brief examination. He then remarked that the tables were weak. This fact you satisfied me of, but that was a few weeks after his visit.

When I had somewhat recovered from the doctor's meeting, I made inquiries as to why I should have been treated so harshly. It appears that at the end of the first week - Oct. 27, 1931, I had mentioned casually to him that I thought that the children would have answered better if examined about practical things. But the occasion of his first visit, he came in a little before two; by this time I had to catch the 11:30 bus, and at once distributed the books he had. There were exchanges, answers read out loud, a mean streak. This was, of course, nothing new to some of the pupils, as nearly all my work is set on the blackboard. Reading, spelling, and the writing of copy or figures furnishes the examination.
We have had a lot of unusual situations and the Indians displayed an
unusual amount of time for the two.

However, however, that Mr. Berry wanted my—what he
called—scheme of his method of education, and spoke—as I
was told—rather harshly of me & myself, when he did not
know the reasons of mine. These facts I learned only recently,
and, in my opinion, explain his behavior toward me.

He has always my aim to teach publicly along the lines
that will serve them best in their state of life. Since these
Indian children are taught any arithmetic that will be to
their advantage. In Chilcotin, the boys needed to change the
large scales, this time also, proper bills etc. There is much
like, measure, counting work, so that they feel confident that
they are getting their due.

Now Mrs. Murray and I have been eighteen years almost
at this work,—two years at the lonely Hope Reserve at
Chilcotin, nine years on the isolated Chilcotin River,
and almost seven here in Chilliwack. Having teaching
been added to the Indians, I am convinced, that my
teaching would have to be other places to which I can find
evidence. My own two daughters were taught at home.
Kathleen, my eldest daughter, was sent to the Indian School
after a few months' preparation and passed the entrance, and
in three years matriculated well, as well as qualifying for
the Normal School. Instead of going to the Normal School, she
entered the Sisters of St. Anne, and has been with them now
for almost five years. My second daughter was never
inside a school until she was eleven. She too qualified
for the Normal School, and though about a year or around
ten minutes, passed the Normal Matriculation obtaining
third place in the Chilliwack High School. I mentioned
facts, and from vanity, but to show what the foundation
they laid within me was solid and lasting.

In dealing with the Indians, my policy has been to
gain the confidence of the parents. By doing, I have attained
an almost very close enough influence to cause them to keep
their children at school. The difficulty of securing regular
attendance in day schools was a very great, and when we
consider the mobility, often clandestine conditions obtaining
in these homes, the wonder is that a teacher is able to
get them to leave the little that many of them possess.

There is one feature in this affair that has disturbed me
more than any other, that is, the treatment by Mrs. Murray.
During her long service she has a spirit of my many problems,
and even in spite of the doctors, undertaken many responsibilities.
She has been called for by Indians or other reasons, not within her care to attend sicknesses of any kind, but she has been doing the best she could in her own way. In 1915, we were alone in the house, she was ill except for one day, and she had to work without any medicine for several days. She had to work without any help from anyone, and she did not have a complaint. This time she was working in another family, and she had none. For the last five years, she has always worked hard, and she has had the assistance of a man, who is a friend of her association with so many bands. She is scarcely a week that some of these outside Indians do not call for attention, so that she has taken on duty and of her time—she will not refuse anyone. Now she has been dropped into the miserable business, and though looked at as a civil servant, for all her good work, she is refused in salary £576.28 a year, and sent to the Babine. This is the fact that disturbs me more than any other. The situation is now a matter of her rights, her absence from this place without proper compensation.

Now in writing this rather long letter, I am not anticipating any favors, though it means the breaking up of our little family, the leaving away of most of our household goods, and going forth in quest of new work, we would not consent to remain, if the Department is of opinion that we are justified in our demands. It will be a great concern to us, but we have sufficient self-respect and, I hope, friend in just to face any difficulties.

You may be surprised at this letter, you are not the first officials of long standing whom we have met with. However, we hold fast what we know you. Nearly four years ago, Mr. Murray and I came to Victoria to see our daughter Kathleen, who was, after a year's separation, being received into the foster of St. John. There we met what proved to be Lady, later Mrs. Murray. She, of course, knew our friend at home, Kathleen, and after some hours with us, invited us to stay with her, she spoke of you affectionately, but we felt that you knew us of the right calibre to appreciate such a fine character. It is this feeling that makes me wish to see this matter in the right light before you, that we may avoid any further misunderstanding, and are quite satisfied to hear this dear news. I am very much obliged to you, and thank you for what you have done, and I hope you will give us all your advice in the matter.

With kind regards & greetings from us both,

Yours sincerely,

J. J. Murray
April 5, 1932.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSCARD.

I have your memorandum of the 31st ultimo, with reference to Mr. J. J. Moroney, teacher of the Skwah Indian Day School, near Chilliwack, B. C. The District Inspector of Indian Schools a year ago reported that he was not very satisfied with Mr. Moroney's school; that he was not prepared to make any special recommendation at that time. In February of this year, pursuant to his inspection, he recommended that Mr. Moroney be removed from his post in June next. The Inspector also recommended, in view of Mr. Moroney's long service, that he be given the appointment of teacher of the Port Babine Indian Day School. Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn concurred in the Inspector's recommendation, and the Department arranged the transfer.

It is true that this meant a reduced salary and perhaps increased living expenses for Mr. Moroney. It is further true that Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, who supervises the work of the Skwah School, felt that Mr. Moroney should be given another chance, as he and his wife had performed useful services outside of the classroom activity. The Department wrote Mr. Ditchburn, asking if he and Inspector Barry could agree to giving Mr. Moroney another opportunity at his present post. Mr. Ditchburn replies that Mr. Moroney's services as a teacher are quite valuable to the Department. He adds that, if the Department has not already notified the teacher with whom Mr. Moroney was to be exchanged, he could agree to another year before making the move. Further, Mr. Ditchburn feels that it is not in the best interests of the work to fail to carry out the recommendations of the Inspector and himself.

On the 2nd instant, after Commissioner Ditchburn's second recommendation had been received, the Department informed Mr. Moroney that he would have to transfer his services.

In view of the representations the Minister has received, I have asked Mr. Ferrier to show you the correspondence, and, if you think wise, to discuss the matter with Mr. H. J. Barber, M. P.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

I wish to refer to the second paragraph in your memorandum of the 23rd instant, concerning the proposed transfer of Mr. J. J. Moroney to the Fort Babine Indian Day School. The Minister raises the question of the advisability of sending Mr. Moroney to Fort Babine if he is wholly incompetent. The proposed transfer is recommended by Mr. Inspector Barry and Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn. The Skwah Indian Day School is in a well settled section of B. C., and the classroom activity is quite comparable to that of a rural public school. On the other hand, Fort Babine is 30 miles from a railroad in northern B. C., and there is required a teacher who is competent in "The Three R's" and who will take an active interest in the affairs of the Indians generally. According to the local Indian agent where Mr. Moroney is now engaged, his services outside of the classroom have been very helpful.

These facts, coupled with Mr. Moroney's long service with the Department, suggested the demotion rather than dismissal. If Mr. Moroney is willing to proceed to the Fort Babine School in the north, does the Minister approve of his appointment.

INFORMATION FOR THE EMPLOYEE

8. Dependents. Taxpayers may claim as dependents only:
   (1) A person wholly dependent on the taxpayer for support and of whom the taxpayer has, or immediately before such person attained the age of twenty-one years did have, in law or in fact, the custody and control.
   (2) Sons and daughters (including illegitimate sons and daughters) or son-in-law or daughter-in-law, brothers and sisters, brothers-in-law or sisters-in-law, and grandchildren, if under eighteen years of age, or under twenty-one and attending school, or over eighteen years of age and incapable of self-support.
   (3) Parents, grandparents, parents-in-law, or grandparents-in-law, incapable of self-support.
   (4) A daughter or sister under twenty-one years of age residing as a minor in a public or provisionally licensed private hospital.

9. If Child Under 16 and Not Registrable for Family Allowances, the taxpayer may claim an exemption of only $100 for a wholly dependent child that was or might have been registered under the Family Allowances Act, 1944, so that an allowance under the said Act was or might have been paid in respect of the child in the month of the taxation year. With a few exceptions, every child under 16 years of age may be registered and receive payments under the Family Allowances Act. Therefore, Form T.D.1 provides that only the $100 exemption may be claimed for any dependent shown in Item 5a as having been born after April 1st, 1940. There are also limitations on the number of children under 16 years of age who are not registrable for family allowances. An employee supporting such a dependent child is entitled to claim the $300 exemption for tax deduction purposes. Therefore, employer receiving a T.D.1 form in which an employee claims the $300 exemption for a child under 16 years of age may make deductions accordingly but he must immediately refer the T.D.1 form to the District Inspector of Income Tax for confirmation, accompanied by a declaration signed by the emp., outlining the facts which substantiate his claim that he is the sole support of a child who is not eligible for registration under The Family Allowances Act.

10. If Income of Spouse Is Excess Of $250. A taxpayer not entitled to claim married status if his/her spouse will have an income of more than $750 during the calendar year. If the spouse will have an income of more than $750 but not more than $750, the exemption permitted for married status shall be reduced by the amount by which the income of the spouse will exceed $250 (e.g., if the spouse’s income will be $600, then the $350 would be entered in Item 6(B) (2), i.e., $300 - $250 = $250). If the spouse’s own income for the calendar year will be not more than $250, Item 6(B) (2) will be left blank and the full marital exemption of $750 entered in Item 6(B) (3).

11. “Self-contained Domestic Establishment” means a dwelling house, apartment or other similar place of residence occupied by at least two persons in which residence amongst other things the taxpayer as a general rule sleeps and has his meals prepared and served. (See Item 10.)

12. Changes in Status or Dependents. If during the year any change occurs in the status or dependents of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form T.D.1.

13. Effect of Change in Status on Form T.D.1. In cases where Form T.D.1 (Revised for Jan. 1947) is not completed and filed with the employer, deductions from all salaries or wages paid on or after January 1st, 1947 must be made if the employee were a single person without dependents even though the employee may have filed a previous Form T.D.1. Single persons without dependents need not file this form.

14. Filing of Income Tax Return. In addition to filing this form you must file your Income Tax Return Form T.1 Special or T.1 General for the calendar year on or before 30th April of the following year.

INSTRUCTIONS TO THE EMPLOYER

15. If Form T.D.1 Not Filed By Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.1 (Revised for Jan. 1947) must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents and deductions made as per column 1 in the table of Income Tax Deductions (1947).

16. Employer to Scrutinize Claims by Single Persons for Married Status. The definition of a “Self-contained Domestic Establishment” contained in Item 10 indicates that the taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status by reason of supporting a dependent therein unless the dependent actually resides with the taxpayer. Therefore, employers are directed to compare the address shown under Item 4(B) or 4(D) with the taxpayer’s own address in Item 2 (which should show where he is actually living at the time of receipt of the declaration) and in every case where the addresses are not the same the employer must make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

17. Employer’s Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.1. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Item 16 above, will check the employee’s computations of the total exemptions in Item 5, and will otherwise make certain that the form is fully completed. He will also delete as a dependent under Item 5 the name of any person whose the employee has already listed in Item 4 unless he claim for married status came within paragraph (B) thereof. If the employer has reason to believe that any of the information on this form is incorrect or false, he will notify the declarant of the error until the employee has made the appropriate confirmation or correction. In case of doubt, the matter should be referred to the District Inspector of Income Tax.

18. Action upon Receipt of Amended Form T.D.1 during Currency of Year. Employees required to file an amended Form T.D.1 if any change occurs in status or dependents. The employer should give immediate effect to a change from “Single” status to “Married” status and an increase in the number of dependents. A change from “Married” status to “Single” status (e.g. if the employee becomes divorced) will not be made effective until the first pay period in the next calendar year because the employee will still be entitled to claim “Married” status for the whole of the preceding year in which the divorce took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally require a change in the deductions until the following calendar year with one important exception. If, for example, a taxpayer does not claim as a dependent any person who has an income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a son who was previously supported as a dependent and was claimed as a dependent on Form T.D.1 takes up employment from which he will earn over $400 during the calendar year, immediate action should be given to the amended Form T.D.1 as otherwise the employee will be left with a substantial balance of tax to pay with his return on Form T.1 Special or T.1 General.

19. Further Information or Forms with respect to deduction of tax may be obtained from any District Inspector of Income Tax.

20. Completed Forms T.D.1 must be Kept on File by the employer in order that they may be available at all times for payroll inspection by officers of the taxation Division.

May 4, 1948.

Dear Mr. Arneil:

Major MacKay and I had an opportunity to discuss your letter of April 22 with Mr. Hoey. As a result I sent you the following telegram:

"HE PERSONAL LETTER MAJOR MacKAY APRIL TWENTY-SECOND HE TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT TWO U. B. C. STUDENTS - stop- PREPARED CLASSIFY THEM AS SEASONAL WELFARE TEACHERS AT SALARY ONE HUNDRED AND FIFTY DOLLARS TEACHING MONTH -stop- DETAILS AS TO TRAVELLING EXPENSES ETC. WILL FOLLOW AIRMAIL LETTER."

As you know only too well, it would take a long time to get these temporary positions established through the Commission. For example, it took me some six months to get two seasonal positions established here for university students this summer. I only wanted them as clerks Grade 2 to help with the requisitions, returns, etc., but it still took a long time for the positions to be established. Therefore it was decided that the easiest way to have these welfare workers employed would be to classify them as welfare teachers on the staffs of two of our Indian day schools. I would suggest that we pay them at the rate of $175.00 a teaching month. This would give them approximately $150.00 as salary and $25.00 towards their travelling expenses. You realize of course that we cannot pay the travelling expenses of our teachers - nor in fact for other seasonal employees, unless we get an Order-in-Council. I presume that you will have one working in the Fraser Valley and the other one on Vancouver Island. If this is the case, we could have one on the staff of the Skwah Indian Day School and the other one on the staff of St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

I hope that the above explains the best

Dear Mr. Arneil:

You will have before you Colonel Neary's airmail letter of May 4th regarding the proposal to employ two U.B.C. students on welfare work this season. The Colonel's letter came to me just when I was leaving the office to keep an appointment, and consequently I did not have time to deal with it. I find, however, that there is nothing of value that I can add other than to say that if you consider it would be more helpful to have the students work in areas other than those suggested, you should so advise Colonel Neary.

Perhaps I should also add that inasmuch as they are to be employed as seasonal welfare teachers, they must in each case be assigned to the staff of an Indian Day School, and information in this regard furnished without delay to the Superintendent of Education.

Ottawa, April 27, 1925.

Sir,

The distressing circumstances attendant upon the resignation of Mr. W. H. Grimshaw, teacher of the Skawah Indian Day School, has again been brought to our attention and it has been decided to make a special arrangement in his case and to grant him salary until the end of the present school year, June 30th, next. Our action in this matter is not to form a precedent, as such cases have to be decided on their individual merit.

The Department is unable to pay him the three months salary until the end of June. We understand, however, that Mr. Grimshaw intends going to England and, if he leaves before June, it is considered that Rev. Father Welch, or some other responsible party, would be willing to advance him the amount that will be paid for his quarterly salary. In the event of him securing the money in this manner, it would be advisable for him to give the party who advances the money, a power of attorney which could be forwarded to the Department and, at the end of the June quarter, the amount due could be paid to the said party.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, February 17, 1932.

Sir:

The Department has decided to make a change at the Skwah Indian Day School at the end of the current academic year. Please inform Mr. and Mrs. Moroney that they are to be transferred to the Fort Babine Indian Day School, in the Babine agency. Mr. Moroney will be allowed salary at $1100 for the ten teaching months and Mrs. Moroney will receive $300 per annum for her services as field matron. Please inform them and ask them for an acceptance in writing of the work at Fort Babine. The Indian Agent at Hazelton is Mr. G. C. Mortimer.

To replace these workers, Mr. and Mrs. C. O. Daly will be moved from Fort Babine to Skwah. Mr. Daly will receive $1000 for the ten teaching months, and Mrs. Daly, $480 per annum as field matron.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

A. O'N. Daunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Establishment of an Indian Day School on the Iona Reserve, near Chilliwack, B.C.

Archbishop MacLell of Vancouver wrote last year suggesting the establishment of a day school for the Indian children in the vicinity of Chilliwack. The Department instructed its agent at Victoria to report on the subject. He reported that there are five reserves in the Chilliwack municipality with forty-two children between the ages of six and fifteen years and that there are also some children on two reserves a couple of miles distant who might attend this school if established.

He reports that the Indians desire to have a school but cannot raise enough money to pay for the building.

The Inspector states "I have no hesitation in saying that a day school conducted by a competent teacher would prove of much benefit to the Indians of Chilliwack and that one should be established large enough to accommodate forty pupils."

Brooks is the only tender received.

It is proposed to put the building on the Iona Reserve as it is the most convenient.

The school would be run under the auspices of the local Catholic Church. The Indian population on the reserve in the vicinity is about 315 Roman Catholics and seventy-three Protestants.

You should also state how you would recommend that the carpenter work in connection with the installing of the windows should be carried out. SIR:-

I beg to forward you herewith an application received from Miss Mabel Boeur, teacher of the Katzie Indian Day School, for extra windows in the School house upon that Reserve.

This application I must thoroughly endorse, and would strongly recommend that it be acceded to. Her explanation I may say, that while the theory of northern lighting for school rooms is doubtless a most excellent one for average climates, it leaves a great deal to be desired in such a damp and gloomy area as the Pacific Coast is in winter time.

I trust that the Department will take the necessary steps to improve conditions of this school, as requested by the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

A.O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Encl.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Making application for windows in the Katzie Indian Day School.

Why are windows needed?

1. Because, for most of the school year, the blackboard cannot be seen.
2. For the same length of time the pupils sitting near the south wall are straining their eyes to see the work on their own side.
3. Although one is continually preaching the doctrine of "sunshine," never a ray enters the class-room where so much of their time is spent.
4. This might be overlooked in a white school, but in a room where most pupils are inclined to be consumptive, sunshine is essential.
5. The air in a room which is never brightened by sunshine becomes so oppressive that even the teacher whose lungs doctors have declared are remarkably strong feels as though she had a flat iron lodged in her chest.
The cause of this dullness.

The gloom which obscures the blackboard, and darkens the wall away from the windows, is due to the location of the Ratzie Reserve, and to the fact that the school is on the bank of the Fraser. Situated in the Fraser Valley, the Reserve is in the heavy rain belt. Usually the rain lasts from September to April. On those days when it does not rain, the darkness is just as bad because such heavy clouds hang low in the sky.

When we do have frosty weather, the Reserve is close enough to the coast to get all the fog. The fog rolls up the Fraser and lies around the schoolhouse for days at a time.
Where are the windows needed?
1. Not being an architect I really do not know, but I would advise putting another in the space marked X. This would throw more light on the blackboard and teacher's desk.
2. To let in sunshine probably windows could be cut on the south wall near the western end. This would let in light but would not affect the children's eyes.

Having taught five successive years in the Katzie Indian Day School I am in a position to know that more windows are needed, and needed badly.

Yours truly,
Mabel Beers
Teacher on the Katzie Indian Reserve.

On the 30th of June, I visited the Day School on Skwah Reserve, under Mr. Daley, teacher. The school was clean and tidy and on the day of my visit there were only four children in class, out of a total of 21 on the roll. This was due to the fact that many of the Indians and their families had already left for the Canneries. The four children that were in school gave me a demonstration of reading, writing and arithmetic, and they showed themselves well up to standard, in fact, very good indeed.

This school requires three storm windows for the exposed side, during the winter. The doors also need fixing, as they have shrunk a lot. Possibly an outside storm door too, would be good. The teacher informs me, and I quite believe him, that it is impossible to keep any heat in the school during east winds. I instructed the Indian Agent to apply for these improvements.

Geo. S. Pragnell
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, August 14, 1933.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Pragnell, in a report on his inspection of the Skwah Indian Day School on June 30th, last, states that three storm windows are required for the exposed side of the building during the coming winter and also that the doors need repairing, as they have shrunk considerably. He states, further, that "possibly an outside storm door would be good", as the teacher informed him that it was impossible to keep the building warm during east winds. Mr. Pragnell advises the Department that he instructed you to apply for these improvements.

If you consider that the above articles are necessary, please give full particulars as to cost involved. Our funds are extremely limited and only the absolutely necessary repairs, to place the building in a comfortable condition during the coming winter, should be requested.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

SIR:-

I beg to forward you herewith, a communication received from Mr. C.O. Daly, Teacher of the Skwah Indian Day School, in which he explains the need of a new wood-shed and submits a Tender from Mr. John M. Nelmes for $55.35 for the wood-shed, with an additional $7.25 if it is painted.

I checked up with local Lumber Yards here, and the best price I received was $85.00 for the material and $15.00 for paint, so the offer of Mr. Nelmes appears reasonable.

This wood-shed was in deplorable condition when I saw it three weeks ago, and I would recommend that authority be given to replace it as indicated. The total cost including paint being $62.60.

SIR:-

I beg to forward you herewith Agency Voucher No.699 for $4.50 in favour of Mr. Vincent Gadzale, representing the standard charge for cleaning chimneys at the Skwah Indian Day School and Teacher's Cottage, as well as cleaning out stove pipes in connection therewith.

Also Voucher No.700 for $5.35 in favour of Messrs. Farquharson and Eckel of Chilliwack, for new pipe for the School house stove.

These were emergency jobs ordered by me when I was in Chilliwack, as from the condition of things, there was no time to refer the matter to Ottawa.

I would recommend that the accounts be paid.

The stove pipes in the School building had been eaten through by creosote drippings from the chimney and both chimneys needed cleaning badly. There was a bitter north east gale blowing off the mountain snows, which rendered it imperative that the chimneys be put in first-class shape at once.

SIR:-

Mr. C.O. Daly, teacher at the Skwah Indian Day School, Chilliwack, has drawn my attention to the condition of the heating stove in the school room.

This is a very old stove, but we thought it would last some time yet, and did not include its replacement in our estimates. In cleaning up this summer, the stove appears so badly burned, that its replacement is advisable, if at all possible.

This school is exposed to bitter winds off the glaciers, during winter, so heavy fires are necessary.

I have obtained quotations for a suitable heater, of the Circulating type from Chilliwack sources, as under:

Menzies Hardware.............$63.00
Davies & Logan...............62.70

The stove pipes should also be taken down, checked, and it may be necessary to replace some parts, but the total expenditure would be under $70.00.

I presume application should be made through the Indian Commissioner, but in view of the fact that this expenditure is not in the estimates, I should be glad if you would inform me whether it would be any use doing so.
