Dear Sir:

Included in my Estimates for the Year 1941-1942, was an amount of $95.00, for repairs to the fence of the Skwah Indian Day School, and Teacher's Cottage. This was based on Tenders, received at the time. Since then, however, prices of materials have advanced, and the fences have still further deteriorated, so that the present quotation, from the previous lowest tenderer amounts to $131.60.

The main entrance steps at the School have collapsed, and must be repaired before school opens. I have obtained a quotation on this work, from Mr. Templier, and which amounts to a further $22.40. This item was not included in the estimates, as there was at the time no indication that it would be necessary.

In addition to the above, the toilet seat in the Teacher's Cottage is in a very bad state of repair, and should be replaced. At the present time, the trap door leading to the basement has no hinges or lock, and this should be remedied, as apart from any personal or private use of the basement, the Department drugs are kept down there, and the Field Nurse should have easier access to it than is the case at the present time. A water faucet is also needed in the basement to be used in connection with the washing and sterilizing of bottles.

Mr. Templier has also quoted on garden hose, but this would probably be a matter of separate purchase. A hose is necessary for the irrigation of the garden, and washing down outside the premises, and the one at present there is completely worn out, and impossible to repair further.

I would recommend that, if possible, this work be authorized. The longer the fences are allowed to remain as they are, the more expensive the repairs become. The steps must also be repaired before the School opens.

I am forwarding you triplicate copies of Mr. Templier's tender in regard to this work.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:-

I beg to forward you herewith, Report, in duplicate, received from Mr. J.W. Burns of the Skwah Indian Day School, in connection with the proposed school garden.

Mr. Burns, the teacher, gives two estimates of the proper fencing of this plot as follows:-

Mr. J.Templier, hog wire fence,----------------$125.00
Matthew Williams, barbed wire fence,-----------31.95

The first estimate is entirely out of the question, and I would recommend that the second estimate of $31.95 be allowed.

I think Mr. Burns' suggestion of planting potatoes is a good one, as the bracken can be eliminated by hoeing during the summer, and it may be possible next year to divide the ground into plots for mixed vegetables. He asks for nine sacks of seed potatoes which would come to approximately $16.00, and if you wish to put in a row or so of carrots, we can put in a little of this seed as well at very small cost. The Indians will not eat beets.

We will also require six garden hoes, three spades and two rakes.

The great trouble with an experiment of this kind is, as I pointed out to Captain Barry, that throughout July, August and September, there will be nobody at the Reserve to look after the garden. We can probably salvage the potato crop, although the weeds which will grow during the three months will not do it any good. The Indians go berry picking, to the canneries and hop-picking during these months, so I am afraid the project will not be a success.

Yours truly,

February 18, 1942.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

The plot of ground at the Skwah Indian Day School to be brought under cultivation as suggested in a letter addressed to you on January 16, by Mr. Indian Commissioner D. M. MacKay, is a little more than an acre in extent. This land has not been plowed or cultivated in the past.

Until a couple of weeks ago the greater part of this area was covered with alder and birch saplings, and, tangled patches of wild brambles. About three weeks ago I managed to interest the Indians in their spare time to clean up the place and, ten days ago I had one of them to plow it. I might mention this work was done without expense to the Department.

The plot is infested with bracken. This noxious weed in season grows here in great profusion and to a height of six and eight feet. So much moisture has been pumped or absorbed from the ground by the weed that the soil is so dry it will not pulverize in its present condition.

When Captain Barry inspected this school in December last, we went over the ground to see if some scheme could be devised to reclaim and develop it. I was anxious something might be done - something that would give to the surroundings which run flush with the public road a more civilized aspect than it has now.

Major MacKay's suggestion to develop the plot into a vegetable garden for the use of the pupils of the school is to be highly commended. But unfortunately, the nature of the ground and the present poor condition of the soil as noted above, would be unsuitable for a vegetable crop this coming season. Until the weed is eliminated, only a thin and scanty vegetable crop can be expected, not enough to pay for the labor.

I have been advised by neighbouring farmers who have kindly looked over the ground, to plant the whole of the plot in potatoes for the next two years. However, I will leave this matter to Major MacKay and yourself to decide.
The next item is the fencing of the ground. This should be properly done if any benefit is to be derived from it now or in future years.

It would appear that when Mr. Daly applied for fencing material a few years ago, there was no intention of cultivating the ground, and he only requested enough of barbed wire as would keep the reserve horses out of the school ground. But this is not near sufficient to keep out a horde of wandering pigs—the fence is not pig-proof.

I had Mr. Joe Templier and an Indian by the name of Matthew Williams go over the ground in the last week. Each has submitted an estimate as given below.

Mr. Templier's Estimate.

(1) Hog Fence—36 inches high, posts, 1 wooden gate 12 feet wide and 5 feet high; labor on same.
Total 125.00

Matthew William's Estimate.

(2) 25 posts $8 each..................4.50
3 spools of barbed wire at $4.50 each...13.50
1 wooden gate complete 12 feet wide and 5 feet high..8.00
17 hours labor at $35 per hr...5.95

Total 31.95

If the Department should consider the first of these two (items) estimates, I would suggest that tenders be called for.

Yours sincerely,

J. W. Burns.

Miss C.E. Finan, Teacher at the Skwah Indian Day School, has requested authority to purchase cocoa, milk, sugar and cookies, to the amount of $5.00 per month, for the children attending the School.

I may say that Miss Finan has already made arrangements with the Ration Board for the necessary sugar coupons.

C., and tender and letter from Indian Agent Gillett in regard to providing fire protection for the Shuswap Indian Village, including Day School and Teacher's cottage, I would say that the Purchasing Agent is today being asked to place an order for the materials and labour with the Elk Creek Waterworks Company, Ltd.

When the Purchasing Agent issues a Purchase Order copy will be sent to Indian Agent Gillett, and he will be asked to have the Elk Creek Waterworks, Ltd. undertake the work as quickly as possible.

Director.
June 20, 1946.

The Departmental Purchasing Agent,

Re: Fire Protection - Similk Indian Reserve.

Some years ago when water was laid on the Indian Reserve equipment for fire protection was provided. This equipment through the years has worn out and the reserve and Day School with Teacher's cottage are now without fire protection.

The Indian Commissioner for British Columbia considers in the recommendation of the Indian Agent that fire protection should be provided, and an estimate of the cost of providing the equipment required and repairing the hose house has been furnished by the Elk Creek Waterworks Company, Ltd., of Chilliwack, from whom the water is secured. This estimate is enclosed.

It is the intention to pay for the work from Band Fund Account No 13th, Interest Account.

Will you kindly issue a Purchase Order in favour of the Elk Creek Waterworks Company, Ltd., for the work which they have estimated will cost $756.00, indicating on the Purchase Order that the cost is to be charged against Account No. 13th.

M.W.

Director.
May 30, 1946

Skwah Indian School
Chilliwack, B.C.

J. Gillett Esq.
Indian Agent
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Mr. Gillett,

When the Indians come to me for medicine and advice, I am obliged (especially during bad weather) to ask them into my own private quarters. This is not always convenient or agreeable.

Last fall, the interior of teacher's cottage was only partly painted and papered, and there are still three rooms which are in a very dirty and neglected condition.

It would therefore greatly facilitate matters if a couple of these rooms could be cleaned and used as dispensary and waiting rooms for the Indians.

Mr. Reimer of Chilliwack, who worked on the school and cottage last year, would be pleased to do the job for about $28.00.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6414, file 844-5, part 3)

Further money allowed last year for cottage furnishings did not go very far. In the Dining Room I have only a dinette table and four chairs. As there are no cupboards in the house, the addition of an inexpensive buffet to the Dining Room set would greatly add to the appearance of the room, and to my convenience and comfort. D. Spencer & Co can supply this odd piece of furniture at $36.50.

Thanking you for approaching the Department on my behalf,

faithfully yours,
Catherine E. Sinclair.
New Westminster, B. C.,
June 14th, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B. C.

Attached is a letter from Miss Finan, teacher at the Skwah Indian Day School, in which she requests improvement and repairs to two rooms in the Teacher's residence for a dispensary.

Mr. Reimer's estimate is reasonable. The two rooms should be cleaned and kilnsmoked, and he will supply the material and labour for $28.00.

I recommend that this be authorized and also the purchase of a buffet from David Spencer Limited, for $36.50, for the teacher's use.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

In order to carry out the work as outlined it would be advisable to have a man and his wife in charge of this school, and as Mr. Grimshaw states in his application, it would be desirable if the Department favourably consider the erection of a small cottage, about four rooms, where the teacher and his family could reside. I believe that the cost of such a cottage would not exceed $1,000.00, and the advantages to the Department and the Indians in having a permanent and satisfactory teacher would be great, as the Indians study very much better under the directions of a teacher with whom they are well acquainted than they would with a stranger.

I may add that at most of the other Indian schools accommodation is provided for the teacher in the same building in which the classes are held, but the building at Skwah being only one story does not allow for this. I would therefore respectfully recommend that the Department favourably consider the erection of a cottage.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo in connection with water supply for the Teacher's residence at Chilliwack Indian Day School, (Skwah) quoting the probable cost of carrying water into the building stating also the minimum meter rates. In reply I have to say that the cost as stated is considerably greater than the Department feels justified in expending for this purpose.

The amount of water that would ordinarily be consumed in the cottage and school would not exceed 100 Imperial gallons per day, or 500 cubic feet per month, at 25¢ per cubic foot is $1.25, this with a 20% discount would reduce the amount to $1.00 per month for the water actually used.

The Department taking into consideration the Company's outlay in providing mains, is prepared to meet them to the extent of paying a minimum of $2.50 per month, which includes the meter rent for the present time, providing they permit of water being carried into the residence, the school, and a hydrant on the street near the school for the use of the Indian village.

Sir,

In reply to Department's letters dated Feb. 11th, and the 13th inst., I beg to submit herewith an estimate of the cost of a water system for the school and teacher's cottage on Skwah Indian Reserve, Chilliwack, B.C., together with a letter from Mr. Menzies, suggesting that it would be more economical to use a gasoline engine, with which to pump the water, instead of a wind engine. The cost of the former, as shown by the estimate, is $160.00, and a three-way pump $18.00, making a total of $178.00; while the cost of a 1½ H.P. gasoline engine, pump and connections is $95.00. The cost of gasoline here, at the present time is 17¢ per gal., and the expense in operating would be very little more than that of the wind-mill. In view of Mr. Menzies' letter on the subject, and the difference in cost, I would respectfully recommend that a gasoline, instead of a wind engine be used.

The Department will please note that the cost of driving a pipe down into the ground is not estimated. This amount may vary considerably in accordance with the depth which the pipe will have to be driven, in order to get the supply of water needed. I regret very much that arrangements could not be made to supply water for domestic purposes, to the Indian village, as it appears to me that it is very necessary, in order to protect them from having to use water from their wells, which is liable at any time to become unfit for use, and which is acknowledged by the Farmers to be very inferior to the water supplied by the Elk Creek Co.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Mr. A. O'N. Daunt, Indian Agent, New Westminster, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 23rd ultimo, the Department approves the purchase of eleven window blinds at a cost of $19.25 for use at the teacher's residence at the Skwah Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have received a request from Miss C.E. Finan, Teacher of the Skwah Indian Day School, to be supplied with blinds at the Teacher's cottage.

This is really very necessary, as naturally there is no privacy when the lights are on at night, unless the windows are covered, and the cottage is situated right alongside a highway.

Messrs. David Spencer Limited, at Chilliwack, quote $19.25 for eleven (11) blinds in plain cream or any dark colour, and I would request authority to furnish the cottage with eleven blinds at this figure.

This School appears to be an expensive proposition, but there were no furnishings of any sort in it to begin with, and now that the place is getting fixed up, there should be no further expense for a long time to come.

A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON BREAK-IN AT SIKAH TEACHERAGE

Some person or persons unknown were reported to have entered the Sika School Teacherage on the week-end of July lst., and accordingly, in company with Constable Wicklow of B.C. Police, I called at the teacherage to investigate damages.

We found that possible entry may have been made through the front door of the building as the glass in the door had been broken. The back door of the building was also open. It would appear that the damages incurred was the work of children.

Certain items of medicine, mainly cod liver oil in bottles, had been stored in a back room—these had been opened and the contents poured out on the kitchen and pantry floors, also on one of the upholstered chairs. Some sort of powder was emptied all over the mattress on the only bed in the building. Pots, pans, and dishes were strewn all over the place, with the majority of the dishes being broken. Constable Wicklow will continue the investigation in an attempt to locate the culprits.

I arranged with Miss Virginia James, an Indian girl who had been hired to clean up the building prior to the break-in, to start immediately to clean up the mess, with the understanding that she would receive at least $16.00 for her work.

I also arranged with the Chilliwack Lumber Yards to install a new glass in the front door, and to place a padlock at the rear. It will be necessary for the Department to purchase, new dishes, pots and pans, two new occasional chairs, and a new mattress, in addition to any other purchases contemplated.

Sir:-

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th inst., No. 558, J. S., inquiring why the arrangements made in 1905 for opening a school on the Sliammon reserve were not carried out.

In reply I beg to state that when I was at Sliammon on the 16th of January, 1906, the Indians purchased Messrs Thulin Bros. Store, with the intention of converting it into a school, and agreed to pay them with logs, but they afterwards refused to pay for the building, as they considered it would cost too much to make the necessary improvements, and informed me that they would put up a new, larger, and more suitable building; but this they have not yet been able to accomplish.

I was under the impression that I had reported this matter to the Department, but on looking up the records in this office, the only reference I can find to it is in my letter of July 4th, 1906, No. 61/7, when forwarding Thulin Bros. cheque for rent on the Sliammon reserve, in which the following paragraph appears:—"In the early part of 1905, the Sliammon Indians agreed to purchase the store building from Messrs. Thulin Bros. for the purpose of converting it

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st instant, No. Q-4-67, on the subject of the application made by the Sliammon band of Indians for the establishment of an Indian day school in their Village and informing me that the Department will agree to pay the customary salary of $300.00 per annum towards a teacher's salary when the school is opened.

In reply I beg to say that as the Indians were uncertain whether their request would be granted or not they did not make the necessary alterations and improvements required on the building to be used for the school, and when authority for establishing the School was received they were away in different parts working and may not be home for some time yet. However the School will be opened as soon as possible.

Andrew Phillip, a young Indian of Chehalis, who has received an excellent education at St. Mary's Mission School has been proposed for teacher of the Sliammon School. Father Bedard, who had charge of his class at the time he graduated from the School, and I have no doubt but that he will be a successful teacher.

The chief customers of the store are logging-camp men who are working near the reserve, and go to the store for their supplies in the evenings after the day's work is done, so that Mr. Browne's tending at the store after school hours, does not interfere with his duties as teacher, and the Indians have made no complaint in this connection. Sir:-

In reply to your favor of the 15th inst., No. 246210/1,
I beg to enclose herewith resignation of Mr. J.W.L. Browne,
teacher of the Sliammon Indian Day School, and would beg to
state that the reasons why I did not transmit this before, are
as follows.

On receipt of Mr. Browne's resignation, I made inquiry
from the Missionary to the Sliammon Indians, Father Wagner, and
also a number of the Indians themselves, and from the best infor-
mation I could gather, I concluded that the whole trouble arose
over the fact that Mr. Browne called in a Doctor from Powell
River to see an old man, who was very ill with a tumor on the
neck. This old man's son-in-law, (Joe Gallihar, who is not an
Indian), was very much offended when asked by the teacher, Mr.
Browne, to look after his father-in-law. Then it appears that
Mrs. Gallihar made some slanderous statements in regard to Mr.
Browne, which as far as I can gather, have no foundation, in
fact.

I then wrote to Mr. Browne and asked him to be good
enough to let his resignation stand over, until I had an oppor-
tunity of visiting Sliammon, and investigate this matter, which
he agreed to do.

Owing to the fact that the fishing and hop-picking
industry are centered in this Agency, and on account of the
Provincial Exhibition being held, it was impossible for me to visit Sliammon until the 13th inst., on which date I arrived there accompanied by Inspector Ditchburn.

I might further state in this connection that at a meeting of these Indians held on their reserve on Saturday the 14th inst., at which Inspector Ditchburn and myself were present, the Chief of this band stated publicly to the meeting, while referring to the charges made against Mr. Browne, that the charges originated amongst some of his people over a year ago, that they had then been taken up, and investigated, and he understood that they had been settled, and he was very sorry to see this trouble resurrected.

In conclusion I may say that Mr. Browne, informed Mr. Ditchburn and myself, while at the reserve, that he was willing to continue teaching until the 1st of April next, or until such time as the Department procured a successor.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:-

In April 1916, I left my position as Teacher of Sliammon Day School, New Westminster Agency, B.C., to join the Overseas Military Forces. At that time you were good enough to keep my situation open for me should I return after the War, a consideration which I fully appreciated.

I would, however, like to bring to your notice, that other Branches of the Civil Service, notably the Post Office, as well as Provincial and Municipal Authorities, Railway Companies, and large Business Firms, such as Eaton's, besides keeping open the positions of their employees who enlisted, also carried them on the pay-roll for a certain period, for the whole or part of their salaries. I know of many such cases; I believe the C.P.R. carried their men for six months at full pay. I have met one man connected with the Law Courts in a certain Province who is having two-thirds of his pay put to his credit all the time he is on Active Service.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of Oct. 31st, re the salary of Mr. William Marsden, teacher of the Indian Day School at Sliammon, came to hand during my absence in the North.

Mr. Marsden has a good education, but no training as a teacher. He took charge of this school in April 1916.

Mr. Marsden is doing good work in the classroom. His work on the whole is satisfactory. He is tidy, energetic, and alert. He is kind and considerate in his treatment of the pupils.

Mrs. Marsden visits the homes of the people. She is taking a special interest in the women and the children of the Reserve. She evinces a keen interest in the physical and moral welfare of the people.

In view of the fact that there is a hospital within two miles of the Village, where medical treatment is available, I would not recommend a Field-Matron.

Dear Sir:

I should like to draw the attention of the Dept. to the fact that I have been holding the position as Teacher here for the last two and a half years on a salary of fifty dollars a month, which I presume was the original amount paid to the first teacher some ten years ago.

As you are aware the cost of living has advanced over a hundred per cent within the last four years in this part of the country. I find my present salary quite inadequate to cover the nearest of living expenses.

There is a janitor's allowance of fifty dollars per year also, which I receive, but this barely covers the fuel necessary to heat the school buildings.

Contrary to the general opinion; living is much higher in a section of country like this, which is non-agricultural, than it is in town; for all provisions, even vegetables, have to be shipped in from the cities, which also entails double freight charges to these outlying places from the nearest shipping point.

I should be glad if the Department could see its way to adjust my salary to meet existing conditions.

I am,

Dear Sir:

It has been brought to my knowledge that outside influences are at work to persuade the Indians of Sliammon, to accept the reinstatement of their previous teacher, Mr Nicholson.

The good Indians of this band realize the detriment that would ensue to their village and children, by the appointment of this man, who by his previous record and intemperate habits, proved himself totally unfit for this position.

Since the possibility of his reinstatement has become known to the Indians, I have had several visits from the parents of the children attending the school, expressing their disgust at such a possibility in no uncertain language, and have begged me and my wife to stay with them, rather than their children should again be under the charge and tuition of a drunken man.

When I volunteered for Indian work and was appointed the teacher at Sliammon, I was informed that Mr Nicholson had been given the option of resigning his position and joining the colors, or being summarily discharged and face the possibility of being sent to prison.

Far be it from me to hinder this man if he wishes to make good again! But if he wants to continue in Indian work let him
at least go where he can hope to have some influence, and not where I
told even the children have constantly seen him in an intoxicated
condition, and witnessed his being carried across the village to his own
quarters in a helpless drunken state.

It is because we have the interest of these Indian children
and their parents at heart, among whom we have lived and worked for
the last three years, that I feel it is my duty to write you on this
matter. If it were to make way for a couple who were at least inter-
ested in the welfare of the Indians,- we would willingly resign, if the
Department so desired- but we cannot relegate these little children,
to the contempt and neglect in which we found them three years ago,
without at least making some protest on their behalf.

Trusting you will give this matter your earliest consideration.

I beg to remain,

Referring to the request of Mr. Basil Nicholson, teacher of the Shuswap Indian Day School, for an increase in salary, which request has been forwarded by Mr. R. S. Clements, M.P., I beg to say that Mr. Nicholson is returned soldier and has three years' experience in teaching before enlistment. Upon his return from overseas he was appointed teacher of this school in September, 1919, with a salary at the rate of $600 per annum and bonus of $150—a combined amount of $750. He has no professional qualifications.

Mr. Nicholson's wife performs the duties of Field Matron, and receives a salary of $460 per annum and bonus of $150, a total of $610. He and his wife thus receive a combined salary and bonus of $1360; besides there is a 6 roomed cottage provided as a teacher's residence.

There is an enrollment of 27 pupils, with an average attendance of 14. Mr. Inspector Cairns, in his last report of inspection, states "The pupils are making progress. All manual work is highly satisfactory. They read, spell, write and do simple number work very well. They are well instructed in letter-writing."

Regarding the bonus to be paid to teachers during the present year, I beg to say that this has not yet been fixed. The bonus to others in the past was paid at the flat rate of $150, which was considerably lower than allowed to Civil Servants. As you are aware, there is a reduction of 25% in the bonus to the Service, but I would suggest, in view of the fact that teachers do not receive the same scale of payment, that their bonus be maintained at the same rate as formerly, viz., $150 per annum. If not, we will no doubt be called upon to make up the difference, which would lead to a further increasing difficulty in obtaining the services of teachers, in view of the fact that teachers in white schools are paid higher salaries than we pay teachers of Indian schools.

In the case of Mr. Nicholson, we might allow him an increase of $100, which would bring his salary up to the amount paid to one or two other teachers in B. C. who have the same qualifications.

Teacher.- Mr. Basil Nicholson. No certificate, but has been in charge of this school over six years. He served here three years, then went overseas for three years and has served three years since returning.

The standard in this school is very low. The pupils are making very slow progress. With the exception of two who are using the First Reader, all other pupils are struggling with word recognition. These pupils, it seems to me, do not use any English in their homes. The teacher is trying to instruct them in the things about them, i.e., he teaches them the days of the week and the months of the year, a little local geography and the names of the food, etc. Their manual work is only fair, both writing and drawing receive attention.

I would be inclined to think that the teacher has not been up to the standard himself. He has been somewhat irregular in opening and closing the school. This has had a bad influence upon the Indians and the pupils, who learn more by example than precept.

I had a heart to heart talk with Mr. Nicholson concerning the management of the school. I told him that unless the pupils were looked after and urged to attend school that the time would soon come when we would have to consider whether the attendance justified the continuance of the school work.

R. H. Cairns,
Insp.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the appointment of a teacher to succeed the late Basil Nicholson as teacher of the Sliammon Indian Day School for the coming school year.

In this connection it is noted you suggest that Miss Mary Wadel, who formerly taught in the Okanagan and Lytton Agencies, be appointed. I would point out that Miss Wadel has no professional qualifications, having attended high school only and finished her junior matriculation. I would request that you refer the matter of her appointment to Mr. Inspector Barry, and, if he is satisfied that her services would be satisfactory, the Department would give favourable consideration to her appointment. If Mr. Barry does not approve of her appointment, I should be pleased if you would take up with him the matter of obtaining the services of a qualified teacher, forwarding full particulars to the Department regarding the qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated.

Regarding the continuing of the services of Mrs. Nicholson as field matron, I have to say that the Department will be pleased to approve of her carrying on the duties in connection with this position, and I shall be pleased if you will advise her accordingly. Her salary will be at the same rate as previously allowed.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith a voucher for $5.00 for work done at Sliammon Day School. The platform was very necessary as the blackboards are permanently fixed to the wall and are much too high. It was cheaper to build a platform than try to lower the blackboards. Some plumbing work is also included in this amount, which, for hygienic reasons, I ordered done on my last visit to the School.

The Department will be pleased to know that this School is proving a real success, attendance has increased threefold, an Indian has donated an organ for school use and the keenest interest is being taken by pupils and parents alike.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that a new heating stove is required for the Sliammon Indian Day School. The one in use is much too small on really cold days but they have carried on with it the best they could.

Last winter the stove cracked in several places and can not be used again this year.

A satisfactory stove can be purchased here for $17.50, the total cost with pipes and freight would be about $21.50 and I respectfully request authority to purchase same.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a requisition for material at the Sliammon Day School. The first eight items are for cleaning the school and school grounds. The milk, sugar and cocoa is to continue supplying the pupils with hot cocoa twice a day and the continuance of this practice is earnestly recommended, especially during the cold rainy months of winter. A hasp and padlock is required for the woodshed as the teacher informs me that fire-wood has been stolen at night.

With regard to the lumber required, a few shelves are needed in the store-room, but the school inspector has recommended a strip of soft lumber about 2'6" wide around three sides of the school-room for the purpose of attaching school work, instructional pictures, etc. At present the teacher is unable to attach anything to the walls as they are too hard. The whole cost of the lumber should not be more than four or five dollars.

This school is making good progress, and I respectfully recommend that the requests be acceded to.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

11 January 1924

Dear Sir,

With reference to the Department's circular of 17th Sept. 1923 changing the system of payment of teachers' salaries, I would like to point out that an adjustment in my favor for $112.50 (my salary is $750 per ann.) for months of July & August 1923 is necessary in order to put the change on an equitable basis. Beginning apparently on 1 Sept. 1923 & ending 1 Sept. 1924 I will have received in salary $750 but in fact this sum covers the period from 1 July 1923 to 1 Sept. 1924 - 14 months, so that unless an adjustment is made as preferred above, I am out $112.50. Other teachers are of course in a similar position, according to amount of their salaries.

I delayed taking this matter up with the Dept. until seeing Mr. Barry Inspector. He was here today & agrees with my view.

I would also respectfully point out that for the period from 1 July last to date, I have only received $75 in salary. Our quarter cheque not being expected to arrive for about a week.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Basil Nicholson
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6415, file 845-3, part 1)
Ottawa, January 21, 1924.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the system of payment of salaries to teachers in Indian day schools.

In reply I beg to say that the Department considers the school year to begin on September 1st and end on June 30th.

Your duties began at the Slingsby Indian Day School September 1, 1919, and from that date to June 30, 1920, you were paid your annual salary in four quarterly instalments of the same amount. For the school years 1920-21, 1921-22 and 1922-23, you were paid in the same manner.

Beginning September 1, 1923, you were paid $75.00 for the month of September, $225.00 for the quarter ending December 31st, and the same amount will be paid you at the end of the March and June quarters. At the end of June next, therefore, you will have received your full yearly salary.

I would point out that in the payment of salaries, the annual summer holidays are not taken into account.

The Department cannot understand why you consider that you will be cut $112.50 owing to the new method of payment. As stated in paragraph three, you formerly received your annual salary of $750.00 in four equal quarterly instalments. At the present time you receive your annual salary at the rate of $1/10 for the month of September and $9/10 for each of the other three quarters. In both cases the full annual salary promised you is being paid.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Basil Nicholson, Esq.,
Box 321, Powell River,
B. C.

11 Nov. 1924

Dear Sir,

I wish to thank you for your letter of result file No. 167-24-3 but am sorry that I do not seem to have made myself clear in my letter of result. The teacher's salary is an annual one and he budgets for his expenditure to cover 12 months on it. The number of instalments or proportion of same in which the salary is paid does not affect the issue rather really does the length of the school year. For instance the salary could be paid in one or any number of payments yet it would be annual & the teacher would calculate living for 12 months on it. Beginning with the new system on 1 Sept. 1923 & ending 31 Aug. 1924, a period of 12 months, the teacher will have received a year's salary & the system works out all right for those entering the service on 1 Sept. 1923. But teachers in the service prior to that date have to live from 1 July 1923 to 31 Aug. 1924 - 14 months - on 12 months salary. They have no money wherewith to meet their expenses of living for two months & again respectfully submit that they are justly entitled to be paid two months salary for July & August 1923, this in my case is $125.00 not $125.00 as stated in error in my letter of result. If this is paid the new system works out all right.

I hope the Department will recognize that the teachers have a just claim in this matter. I am really very sorry to
trouble the Department by writing again but am sure you will appreciate the fact of the amount involved being a considerable one to the trackers. I really have no money to meet my bills for last July & August.

I entered the service of the Department on 13 Novt 1913, taking charge of this school. I re-commenced my service after the war on 14 May 1919.

Your obedient servant

Darel Nicholson

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th inst., with reference to the June quarter salary of the late Basil Nicholson. Cheque for this salary has been duly received and handed over to Mrs. Nicholson who requests me to express her appreciation for it.

I sincerely hope something can be done for the family. The insurance is $700.00 which, with the salary cheque, is less than $1000.00. There are three sons, the eldest working in the Canadian Bank of Commerce in Vancouver. The second son will now leave school and I believe is to given employment by the Powell River Pulp and Paper Co.; the youngest son will continue in school.

Everyone speaks in the highest terms of Basil Nicholson's integrity and I have found him to be the soul of honour in all his dealings with the Indians, who trusted him absolutely. The Nicholsons were an exceptionally happy and united family, well liked by the people of Powell River, and the three sons show the results of their home training.

Mrs. Nicholson will carry on as field matron, and a teacher will stay on the Reserve with her. I am sure that anything which the Department will do for them in the way of a gratuity will be deeply appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

Sir:

I have been requested by the teacher of Sliammon Indian Day School to apply for a Coleman lamp for the school. When this teacher, Mr. D.J. Gallagher, was at Homalco School he held classes in the evenings for adults and was quite successful. His idea is to encourage the parents to take an interest in the school in something like a parent-teacher association. This work, of course, is voluntary on the teacher's part, and he says it gives him employment for the long winter evenings when there is nothing else to occupy his mind other than reading.

One result of these evening sessions was the big increase in attendance of the pupils, some of whom scored 100% per term.

If this lamp can be supplied, I would like to see Mr. Gallagher encouraged in his voluntary work; although I do not mention it to influence your decision, I might add that it would also be very useful to me when I hold meetings of this Band - usually I have to work by the light of a small oil lamp, the people being practically invisible in the darkness of the room. Nearly all Bands here hold their meetings in the afternoons and evenings.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

(F.J.O. Bell)
Indian Agent.
